Award.AwardTitle: Conference: Pedagogical Initiatives in Linear Algebra

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This IUSE conferene project, Pedagogical Initiatives in Linear Algebra, will develop, hold, and follow up on a conference for 55 faculty in the U.S. The two-day workshop will include mathematicians and mathematics educators listening to plenary talks and panel discussions by experts in the field. They will then work together to examine current issues in Linear Algebra teaching and learning and to develop new pathways for studying and implementing more evidence-based teaching. The project aligns with the national effort to improve STEM Education by introducing and refining research-based strategies for the teaching of linear algebra, and more broadly, other proof-based mathematics courses at the undergraduate level.

The project goals are: a) move forward on producing an instructional and research guide for linear algebra (first course and second course); (b) work toward writing research- based recommendations for teaching and learning of linear algebra; (c) generate new research questions; and (d) encourage collaboration between research mathematicians and mathematics educators. The products after the conference will be plans to develop and publish a new instructional guide for teaching linear algebra, curricula recommendations, and a themed journal publication.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In Fall 2018, the PI held an NSF funded 2-day workshop titled, National Pedagogical Initiatives on Linear Algebra. She invited 27 mathematicians and mathematics educators from around the US to participate in this workshop at the University of Oklahoma (OU). Many faculty members, as well as students from the OU mathematics department, were also invited. The PI also invited a few colleagues from the Engineering and Computer Science departments to participate in a panel discussion. The goals of this 2-day workshop included:

(a) producing an instruction guide for linear algebra (first course and second course); (b) writing research-based recommendations for teaching and learning of linear algebra; (c) generating new research questions and inviting the attendees in research ideas that encourage collaboration between research mathematicians and mathematics educators.

The workshop included nine sessions and two plenary talks. This workshop for the first time brought the mathematicians and mathematics educators who are currently working on linear algebra under one roof and was extremely fruitful. Many participants shared ideas and expressed their willingness to help with this important project. The participants acknowledged the important work that was started by the Linear Algebra Curriculum Study Group (LACSG) in the 90s, however, agreed that those recommendations needed to be revised.

Immediately after the workshop, the PI formed an executive committee and in March 2019, the newly formed committee (LACSG 2.0) met and discussed the appropriate modifications to the original recommendations at a subsequent workshop at the University of Oklahoma. At this workshop, it was decided to move the next and last workshop of LACSG 2.0 to Tacoma, Washington in August 2019. The main reason was to make contacts with users of linear algebra such as Amazon, Juniper, Schweitzer, Nordstrom (AI division), Boeing, and Microsoft. Since the goal of this newly formed committee was to revise the curriculum study guide, the committee believed that meeting with the clients from industry would be of enormous benefit.  In August 2019, the committee invited a panel from industry in the Washington area and met at the University of Puget Sound in order to gain insights on the needs of the industry regarding linear algebra. This meeting was informative, and the committee was able to gather valuable information on what aspects of linear algebra should be emphasized in the curriculum and consequently in its instruction. During this last workshop, the committee also spent a significant portion of the workshop writing drafts of the various sections of the recommendations and discussed them further. 

These new recommendations will be sent to the linear algebra community for their feedback. Once feedback is received and is stabilized, it will be incorporated in the draft of the LASCG 2.0 recommendations and will be shared with the larger community of potential audiences. The final product of LACSG 2.0 is expected to involve several cycles of deliberation involving research and will be submitted to the College Mathematics Journal where the first recommendations were published.

 A report about this workshop was published in IMAGE (Issue number 61), which is the Bulletin of the ILAS (International Linear Algebra Society) in December 2018.  In January 2019, the PI gave a talk at the Joint Math Meetings in Baltimore. In her talk, she gave a report about the workshop and engaged the audience on the importance of linear algebra education.

The PI will invite the participants from the linear algebra workshop to react to the LACSG 2.0 recommendations and publish them in the form of an edited volume. In addition, the PI is seeking to apply for more funding to sustain and maintain the future activities of this project. The newly established national project (LACSG 2.0) will lead the work on linear algebra to the next level, by revising the previous recommendations and creating new ones in line with our current research. Furthermore, the outcomes of this project will have a significant impact on the body of mathematics education literature, by creating new pathways and directions for research and guiding and nurturing the new researchers. 

Linear algebra is an important subject for other STEM fields. Our close attention to developing the curriculum and engaging in innovative teaching of the topic using technology and applications will affect other disciplines in a very productive and positive way. In addition, it will increase collaborations between the STEM disciplines.  The committee has made an initial and crucial connection with the industry. We hope to develop these further and learn more about how to train students more adequately for tomorrow's job market.
